verses.text: Abimelech the son of Jerubbaal went to Shechem, to his mother’s brothers, and spoke with them and with all the family of the house of his mother’s father, saying,
verses.comment: Abimelech is introduced as Jerubbaal’s (Gideon's) son, reflecting the Hebrew wording.

verses.text: "Please speak in the ears of all the leaders of Shechem, saying, ‘Which is better for you, that all seventy of the sons of Jerubbaal rule over you, or that one man rule over you?’ Remember also that I am your own bone and flesh."
verses.comment: "Bone and flesh" is a direct expression from Hebrew idiom meaning close relative.

verses.text: And his mother’s brothers spoke all these words on his behalf in the ears of all the leaders of Shechem, and their hearts inclined to follow Abimelech, for they said, "He is our brother."
verses.comment: "He is our brother" is literal from the Hebrew.

verses.text: And they gave him seventy pieces of silver out of the house of Baal-berith, with which Abimelech hired worthless and reckless men, who followed him.
verses.comment: "Worthless and reckless men" follows the literal meaning of the Hebrew.

verses.text: And he went to his father’s house at Ophrah and killed his brothers, the sons of Jerubbaal, seventy men, on one stone. But Jotham, the youngest son of Jerubbaal, remained, for he hid himself.
verses.comment: "On one stone" is a literal translation; implies execution style.

verses.text: And all the leaders of Shechem gathered together, and all Beth-millo; and they went and made Abimelech king, by the oak of the pillar at Shechem.
verses.comment: "Oak of the pillar" is literal, matching the historical marker in Shechem.

verses.text: When they told Jotham, he went and stood on top of Mount Gerizim, and he lifted up his voice and called out, and said to them, "Listen to me, you leaders of Shechem, that God may listen to you.
verses.comment: Mount Gerizim was historically a place of blessing and proclamation.

verses.text: "The trees once went out to anoint a king over themselves. And they said to the olive tree, ‘Reign over us!’
verses.comment: This verse starts Jotham's fable, a direct translation of the parable format.

verses.text: But the olive tree said to them, ‘Shall I leave my fatness, by which gods and men are honored, and go wave over the trees?’
verses.comment: “Gods and men” is literal; some manuscripts have “God and men.”

verses.text: Then the trees said to the fig tree, ‘You come and reign over us.’
verses.comment: Literal continuation of the fable.

verses.text: But the fig tree said to them, ‘Shall I leave my sweetness and my good fruit, and go wave over the trees?’
verses.comment: Maintains the metaphorical speech from the fable.

verses.text: And the trees said to the vine, ‘You come and reign over us.’
verses.comment: Faithful to the parable's narrative.

verses.text: But the vine said to them, ‘Shall I leave my wine, which cheers God and men, and go wave over the trees?’
verses.comment: "Cheers God and men" follows the literal, debated meaning. Could mean bringing joy to both.

verses.text: Then all the trees said to the bramble, ‘You come and reign over us.’
verses.comment: "Bramble" translates the Hebrew 'atad', meaning a thornbush or weed.

verses.text: And the bramble said to the trees, ‘If truly you anoint me as king over you, then come and take refuge in my shade; but if not, let fire come out of the bramble and devour the cedars of Lebanon.’
verses.comment: "Refuge in my shade" is ironic, as bramble provides no real shade.

verses.text: "Now therefore, if you acted in truth and uprightness in making Abimelech king, and if you have dealt well with Jerubbaal and his house, and have done to him as he deserved—
verses.comment: "Truth and uprightness" are direct from Hebrew words for faithfulness and integrity.

verses.text: for my father fought for you, and risked his life and delivered you out of the hand of Midian;
verses.comment: Direct recounting of Gideon's deliverance.

verses.text: but you have risen up against my father’s house this day and have killed his sons, seventy men on one stone, and have made Abimelech, the son of his female servant, king over the leaders of Shechem, because he is your relative—
verses.comment: Faithfully translates the phrase "son of his female servant" (concubine).

verses.text: if then you have acted in truth and uprightness with Jerubbaal and with his house this day, then rejoice in Abimelech, and let him also rejoice in you;
verses.comment: Direct rendering conveys sarcasm of Jotham’s speech.

verses.text: but if not, let fire come out from Abimelech and devour the leaders of Shechem and Beth-millo; and let fire come out from the leaders of Shechem and from Beth-millo and devour Abimelech."
verses.comment: Prophetic curse against both parties, literal translation.

verses.text: And Jotham ran away and fled, and went to Beer and lived there, for fear of Abimelech his brother.
verses.comment: Place 'Beer' means 'well'; translation follows Hebrew.

verses.text: Abimelech ruled over Israel three years.
verses.comment: Simple historical note; no title given to Abimelech beyond 'ruled.'

verses.text: And God sent an evil spirit between Abimelech and the leaders of Shechem, and the leaders of Shechem dealt treacherously with Abimelech,
verses.comment: "Evil spirit" is literal from Hebrew. God as sovereign cause.

verses.text: that the violence done to the seventy sons of Jerubbaal might come, and their blood be laid on Abimelech their brother, who killed them, and on the leaders of Shechem, who helped strengthen his hands to kill his brothers.
verses.comment: "Strengthened his hands" is a Hebrew idiom meaning 'helped'.

verses.text: And the leaders of Shechem set ambushes on the mountaintops against him, and they robbed all who passed by along the way. And it was told to Abimelech.
verses.comment: Ambushes intended to harm Abimelech’s interests.

verses.text: And Gaal the son of Ebed came with his relatives and moved into Shechem, and the leaders of Shechem put their confidence in him.
verses.comment: Literal naming, 'Gaal son of Ebed.'

verses.text: And they went out into the field, gathered the grapes from their vineyards, trod them, and made merry, and went into the house of their god and ate and drank and cursed Abimelech.
verses.comment: "Made merry" translates a Hebrew idiom for festival celebration.

verses.text: And Gaal the son of Ebed said, "Who is Abimelech, and who is Shechem that we should serve him? Is he not the son of Jerubbaal, and is not Zebul his officer? Serve the men of Hamor, the father of Shechem; but why should we serve him?"
verses.comment: Hamor is the historic founder of Shechem’s ruling family (per Gen. 34).

verses.text: If only this people were under my hand! Then I would remove Abimelech. He said to Abimelech, "Gather your army and come out!"
verses.comment: "Gather and come out": literal challenge to fight.

verses.text: When Zebul, the ruler of the city, heard the words of Gaal the son of Ebed, his anger was kindled.
verses.comment: "Anger kindled" is from the literal Hebrew wording.

verses.text: And he sent messengers to Abimelech secretly, saying, "Behold, Gaal the son of Ebed and his relatives have come to Shechem, and they are stirring up the city against you.
verses.comment: Literal translation including 'behold.'

verses.text: Now therefore, go by night, you and the people who are with you, and lie in wait in the field.
verses.comment: Military strategy is literally described.

verses.text: And in the morning, as soon as the sun is up, rise early and rush upon the city. And when he and the people who are with him come out against you, you may do to them whatever your hand finds to do."
verses.comment: "Whatever your hand finds to do" is a literal Hebrew expression.

verses.text: So Abimelech and all the people with him rose up by night and laid in wait against Shechem in four companies.
verses.comment: "Four companies" translates the Hebrew phrase for four groups/troops.

verses.text: And Gaal the son of Ebed went out and stood in the entrance of the gate of the city; and Abimelech and the people who were with him rose up from the ambush.
verses.comment: Faithfully translates locations, per Hebrew.

verses.text: And when Gaal saw the people, he said to Zebul, "Look, people are coming down from the mountaintops!" But Zebul said to him, "You see the shadow of the mountains as if they were men."
verses.comment: "Shadow of the mountains" keeps the ambiguity from the Hebrew.

verses.text: And Gaal spoke again and said, "Look, people are coming down from the middle of the land, and one company is coming from the direction of the Diviner’s Oak."
verses.comment: "Diviner’s Oak" is a literal rendering; the tree was associated with oracular activity.

verses.text: Then Zebul said to him, "Where now is your mouth, with which you said, ‘Who is Abimelech that we should serve him?’ Are not these the people whom you despised? Go out now and fight with them."
verses.comment: "Where now is your mouth" is a Hebrew taunt meaning "Where is your boast?"

verses.text: And Gaal went out before the leaders of Shechem and fought with Abimelech.
verses.comment: Direct recounting; 'before' means 'in the sight of.'

verses.text: And Abimelech chased him, and he fled before him; and many fell wounded up to the entrance of the gate.
verses.comment: Literal translation of battle aftermath.

verses.text: And Abimelech lived at Arumah, and Zebul drove out Gaal and his relatives so that they would not dwell in Shechem.
verses.comment: Faithful to place names and events.

verses.text: And it came to pass the next day, the people went out into the field, and Abimelech was told.
verses.comment: "And it came to pass" preserves the Hebrew narrative style.

verses.text: And he took the people and divided them into three companies, and set an ambush in the field. And he looked, and behold, the people were coming out of the city, so he rose against them and struck them.
verses.comment: Military tactics are translated directly.

verses.text: And Abimelech and the company with him rushed forward and stood at the entrance of the gate of the city, and the two other companies rushed upon all who were in the field and struck them.
verses.comment: Keeps literal divisions of the attacking forces.

verses.text: And Abimelech fought against the city all that day. He took the city, killed the people who were in it, and razed the city and sowed it with salt.
verses.comment: "Sowed it with salt" is a sign of total destruction.

verses.text: When all the leaders of the Tower of Shechem heard of it, they entered the stronghold of the house of El-berith.
verses.comment: "Stronghold" is literal, indicating a fortified room or tower.

verses.text: Abimelech was told that all the leaders of the Tower of Shechem were gathered together.
verses.comment: Literal sequence.

verses.text: And Abimelech went up to Mount Zalmon, he and all the people who were with him; and Abimelech took an axe in his hand and cut down a branch from the trees, and lifted it and laid it on his shoulder. Then he said to the people with him, "What you have seen me do, hurry and do as I have done."
verses.comment: Translates the direct instructions and actions of Abimelech.

verses.text: So all the people also cut down each his own branch and followed Abimelech, and put them against the stronghold, and set the stronghold on fire over them; so that all the people of the Tower of Shechem died, about a thousand men and women.
verses.comment: Preserves the literal numbers and details.

verses.text: Then Abimelech went to Thebez, and he camped against Thebez and captured it.
verses.comment: Place names are direct.

verses.text: But there was a strong tower in the city, and all the men and women, all the leaders of the city, fled there and shut themselves in and went up to the roof of the tower.
verses.comment: Details of defense strategy, translated directly.

verses.text: And Abimelech came to the tower and fought against it, and drew near to the door of the tower to burn it with fire.
verses.comment: Describes Abimelech's repeated tactic.

verses.text: But a certain woman threw an upper millstone on Abimelech’s head and cracked his skull.
verses.comment: "Upper millstone" is literal; women typically operated such stones.

verses.text: Then he called quickly to the young man, his armor-bearer, and said to him, "Draw your sword and kill me, so that they may not say of me, ‘A woman killed him.’" So his young man thrust him through, and he died.
verses.comment: Pride and shame in death; literal rendering.

verses.text: And when the men of Israel saw that Abimelech was dead, they departed, every man to his home.
verses.comment: Standard Hebrew closing for a battle.

verses.text: So God repaid the wickedness of Abimelech that he did to his father by killing his seventy brothers.
verses.comment: Interprets the event as divine judgment, as the original.

verses.text: And God returned all the wickedness of the men of Shechem on their heads, and upon them came the curse of Jotham the son of Jerubbaal.
verses.comment: Verse closes with mention of Jotham’s curse—literal rendering.
